Author: Trans-word plus TGM
Review:
Toyokuni Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Higashiyama-ku. It was built in 1599 to commemorate Toyotomi Hideyoshi who was one of the 3 greatest unifiers of Warring States Period of Japan. It is the location of the first tamaya ( a Shinto altar for ancestor worship ) ever constructed, which was later destroyed by the Tokugawa clan to forbid the worship of Toyotomi.

This shrine is the official tomb and shrine of Toyotomi Hideyoshi, who died in 1598 in Kyoto.

Nobles, priests, warriors, and townspeople gathered at the shrine to celebrate the anniversary of Hideyoshi's apotheosis  Á•û„Å®„Åó„Å¶Á•Ä„Çã„Åì„Å®„ÄÄwith banquets, musical recitals, and boisterous festivity. The shrine was closed by Tokugawa Ieyasu in June 1615 "to discourage these unseemly displays of loyalty to a man he had eclipsed."

The Meiji Emperor directed that the shrine be restored in 1868. In 1897, the tercentenary  ÔºìÔºêÔºêÂπ¥Ë®òÂøµ  of Hideyoshi was celebrated at this site.

( Trans-word+ TGM )

Author: aaron meldahl
Review: A shrine dedicated to Hideyoshi Toyotomi, who started out as a lowly assistant and ended up as the reunifier of Japan and its most powerful ruler at the time. It's nothing to go out of your way for, but might as well stop by if you're in the area. Good views to the west and you can get a strap with little golden sandals to wish for promotion or advancement.

Author: Hide Miya
Review:
Toyokuni Shrine

July 29, 2019 Kyoto early summer trip

It is Toyokuni Shrine that enshrines Toyotomi Hideyoshi.
After the fall of the Toyotomi family, it was abolished by Ieyasu's order, but it has a history of being revived by Emperor Meiji's imperial order!
The highlight is the Karamon designated as a national treasure, but at this time it was under restoration work!
Still, I was able to go to the side and see it (^^;;

Author: Troy Friedman

Author: Ëä±Áî∞„ÅÑ„Å°„Çç
Review:
If you go to the north side of the parking lot, there is a huge bell of Hokoji Temple.
It is a bell with the famous story of "National peace and well-being" written on it, so Ieyasu's name was snipped off and it was called Ichamon.
If you pay 300 yen at the shrine office and buy an admission ticket for the Treasure Hall, you can also get a simple pamphlet.
The Mausoleum of Toyokuni is located at the top of the mountain at the end of the slope to the east of the Kyoto National Museum, so I think it would be good to go there as well.
You can climb Toyokuni Mausoleum by putting 100 yen in a box, but it is recommended to pay 100 yen at the shop and listen to the story of Uncle Toyokuni Mausoleum before climbing.
The view of Kiyomizu-dera from the north side of the five-ring pagoda at the top is wonderful.

Author: ‰∏ÉÈù¢È≥•ÊîæÊµ™Ë®ò
Review:
The National Treasure Karamon Gate is majestic enough, but it is clearly floating in the precincts, which is almost like a parking lot. It's a pity because the shrine building seen from the ruins of the Great Buddha Hall of Hokoji Temple is splendid in its own way, and the precincts of the temple can be greatly enhanced depending on how it is presented. The feeling of treasure is whether or not there is an eye-catching treasure on display. Miyajima's Itsukushima Shrine reminds us of the prosperity of the Heike clan, but Toyokuni Shrine makes us feel the decline of the Toyotomi clan. It is said that there used to be the precincts of Toyokuni Shrine up to around Chishaku-in, but now there is no trace of it.

Sanjusangendo Temple, Chishakuin Temple, and the National Museum are nearby, so I think it's a good shrine to drop by without expecting too much.

Author: 0128 Y
Review:
Walking distance from Sanjusangendo.
A shrine dedicated to Toyotomi Hideyoshi.
It's not a mausoleum, it's a grave somewhere else.
Perhaps because of that, the shrine was refreshing, and I was able to visit the shrine comfortably with the bright voices of a group of elementary school students. (Some shrines are heavy and dark.)
It was destroyed by Ieyasu Tokugawa after the Summer Siege of Osaka, and was rebuilt in the first year of the Meiji era by Emperor Meiji.
The splendid Karamon gate is said to have been relocated from Fushimi Castle and is a national treasure.
It was a very beautiful gate.

Author: „Éû„É≠„Éû„É≠
Review:
It is known by the name of Toyokuni Shrine (Houkoku-san), where Hideyoshi Toyotomi, the ruler of Japan, is enshrined.
After the fall of Hideyoshi, it was abolished by the Tokugawa shogunate, but was rebuilt on the site of the former Hokoji Great Buddha Hall (this site) in 1880.
The huge hanging bell of the adjacent Hokoji Temple
Ieyasu became enraged at the words (National Anxiety) and (Kim and Omi Toyoraku) engraved on the hanging bell. It is a fishing bell with a history.
The Karamon Gate (National Treasure) in front was relocated from Fushimi Castle and is the Karamon Gate of Daitokuji Temple and Nishi Honganji Temple.
Together, it is one of the three national treasure gates.

Author: „ÅÇ„Å®„Çä
Review:
Visited on 13/01/21.

This is a shrine that enshrines Hideyoshi Toyotomi as Toyokuni Daimyojin.
After the fall of the Toyotomi family, it was abolished by the Tokugawa Shogunate, but was relocated to its current location in the Meiji period and rebuilt.

The Karamon gate (national treasure) is said to have been relocated from Fushimi Castle and is considered one of the three national treasures along with the Karamon gates of Nishi Honganji and Daitokuji.

Karamon was a chic black and gold Karamon.
Also, it was interesting to see the water coming out of the gold gourd in the chozuya.

I received a limited goshuin of "Kyoto Touken Goshuin Meguri". It was with the clip of the conferment item.

Author: ukamuse k
Review:
The enshrined deity is Toyotomi Hideyoshi.
In 1598, Hideyoshi's body was buried at Amida-gamine in Higashiyama, and a magnificent shrine was built on the hillside the following year. After the fall of the Toyotomi clan, it fell into disrepair, but in the first year of the Meiji era, the Kaguraden of Shin-Hiyoshi Jingu was rebuilt as a temporary main hall, and a new shrine was built on the grounds of the former Great Buddha Hall of Hokoji Temple. The Karamon Gate, a National Treasure, is said to be the remains of Fushimi Castle, and was moved from Nijo Castle to Nanzenji Temple's Konchiin Temple. I'm here. It is said that the stone lanterns next to the Karamon gate were donated by feudal lords at the time.

Author: JACKPOT
Review: Kyoto Summer Trip 2021, Mystery of Kyoto and Legend of the Makai, Toyokuni Shrine is famous for one of the legendary swords, Toshiro Kotsubami. The Shoin and Treasure Museum, which are usually closed to the public, are open to the public, and the real Kotsubami Toshiro, which is owned by the National Museum, is open to the public for the first time in 30 years. In the study, you can see the folding screen (replica) of the Toyokuni Festival up close, and the hanging scroll written by Hideyori himself is also a highlight. In the treasure hall, specialties related to Hideyoshi are lined up, and you can study. And above all, the real body of Toshiro Kotsubami and a copy of the sword are displayed side by side, which is impressive enough. It is worth mentioning that photography is free in both the treasure hall and the study hall, so it is irresistible for camera lovers.

Author: m78 m
Review: I visited to see Kotsubami Toshiro, which is shown in Kyo no Natsu no Tabi. Fortunately, photography is OK. When I went there, it was almost completely reserved, so I took a lot of photos. I thought that the Homotsukan was a very old building, so when I asked about it, I was very surprised to learn that it was built in 1925 and soon turned 100 years old. The display cases are also from those days, and the distortion of the Taisho glass made the many valuable exhibits look even more tasteful. The staff was polite and the explanation was easy to understand.

Author: ÂÆâÈÉ®ËºùÊµ©
Review:
A shrine dedicated to Toyotomi Hideyoshi. There is only a famous shrine, and the atmosphere is solemn and good.
When you pass through the torii gate, you will be greeted by the seated statue of Toyotomi Hideyoshi.
The fact that it has been covered with gold leaf and has survived beautifully to this day is probably a sign of its popularity.
There is Sanjusangendo Temple nearby, so we recommend visiting them together.

Author: ÂÆÖË¶ãËÇá
Review:
About a 5-minute walk from Shichijo Station on the Keihan Railway, there is a small shrine that enshrines Toyotomi Hideyoshi as the god of success and fortune.

The splendid Karamon, a National Treasure, the water for washing hands that comes out of a golden gourd named after Hideyoshi, and the votive tablet named after Sennari gourd are places where you can feel Hideyoshi's personality.

There is also Mimizuka, which was a memorial tower for the dispatch of troops to Korea, and Horsemound, which is said to have been moved by people who admired Hideyoshi after the former Toyokuni Shrine was demolished.
In the back of the building, there is a museum called Treasure Museum, which displays items related to Hideyoshi. (Admission 300 yen)
Starting with iron lanterns, folding screens of festivals, swords and armor, etc. Hideyoshi fans may be pleased, but Toyokuni Shrine, which was originally built at Amida-gamine peak, was 300,000 tsubo (300,000 tsubo). I feel lonely when I hear that. If you go to the neighboring Hokoji Temple, you will feel even greater change in history and regret.

History is always fabricated and circulated for the sake of the victors, and the winners are right. The loser will only be silent on the opposite bank!

Author: Jodie James
Review: Cute little shrine with lovely trinkets and fortunes.

Author: RAIMU R120
Review:
This is a shrine where Hideyoshi Toyotomi and Taiko's grave are enshrined. He is a person that every Japanese person knows, and he is a splendid person who achieved the unification of Japan.
There are many wonderful things that are said to have been made by Hideyoshi Toyotomi. I also heard that it was made to do.
I had passed by many times without knowing that this was the grave of Toyotomi Hideyoshi. I have been to Tokugawa Ieyasu's Nikko Toshogu Shrine, thinking that there must be something more splendid built somewhere else, so I was deeply moved by the difference.

Author: JP
Review:
Toyokuni Shrine was enshrined near Kiyomizu Gojo. A shrine that enshrines Toyotomi Hideyoshi, a symbol of success in Japanese history. Personally, I don't really visit shrines that enshrine real people, but... I want to take part in the divine virtues of good luck in my career.
Toyokuni Shrine seems to have been abolished by Ieyasu's orders when the Toyotomi clan fell in the Edo period... Was Ieyasu so afraid of Hideyoshi? However, it seems that it was revived by the imperial order of Emperor Meiji.
The most eye-catching part of the precincts is the Karamon Gate, a national treasure. The Karamon gate, which is said to be the remains of Fushimi Castle, was overwhelmed by its majestic structure and beauty, reminiscent of a samurai family.

Author: ‰∫òÂæπÂ§™ÈÉé
Review:
The temple bell that was used as an excuse for the Siege of Osaka during the Warring States period still exists.
In the past, it was hung loosely on the side of the street and could be seen for free, but in 2022, it was not maintained, either it was moved inside or it was in a pay zone. No, if you look closely, the bell is enshrined on the north side! I will upload the description image.

It is said that during the Sengoku period, there was a Great Buddha that was even bigger than the Great Buddha of Nara, but after Hideyoshi's death, it has been devastated to the present day. It's good that it's been fixed.

Author: Tomocaz Sight
Review: A shrine that shows the power of Toyotomi during the Sengoku period. It was rebuilt in its current location by the Meiji government. Karamon was relocated from Nanzen-ji Konchi-in and is the remains of Fushimi Castle. Adjacent to Hokoji Temple, which has a temple bell famous for the incident that triggered the Winter and Summer Siege of Osaka, there used to be a Great Buddha Hall on the east side of the shrine, but now only the remains remain.

Author: JH Jung
Review:
A shrine for Toyotomi Hideyoshi, who kept the shabby Korean ear tomb as a spoil of war.
On the day I visited, a young Japanese couple was holding a wedding ceremony amidst the congratulations of both families.

Toyotomi is respected and admired by the Japanese, but is a person who gave Koreans the deep pain of war.
It is a history of hundreds of years in the past, but standing in front of the ear tomb at the present moment makes me think about the importance of the country once again.

King Seonjo was the first to flee from the capital, Hanyang.
President Syngman Rhee abandoned Seoul, the capital, and blew up the Hangang Bridge and fled alone.
History shows well how the country and its people suffer when they meet incompetent leaders, both in the past and in the present.

Even so, if you don't realize it from history, the people will really say there is no answer.

Author: I H
Review:
I visited on August 15, 4th year of Reiwa.
Get off at Hakubutsukan Sanjusangendo-mae by city bus and go there within a 10-minute walk.

This shrine, which enshrines Toyotomi Hideyoshi, is said to have originally been located halfway up Amidagamine. After the fall of the Toyotomi clan, it was destroyed by the Tokugawa Shogunate. However, times changed and in the 13th year of the Meiji era, the Meiji government praised Hideyoshi's virtues and restored it to the ruins of the Great Buddha Hall of Hokoji Temple.

The Karamon, a national treasure, is said to have been relocated from Fushimi Castle.

Within the precincts, there is also Sessha Teiteru Shrine, which enshrines Hideyoshi's wife Kita no Mandokoro.

There is a rare Sennari gourd ema named after Hideyoshi's horse mark. Write a wish on the ema and dedicate it to Karamon. The gourd-shaped ema is very impressive.

In front of the Karamon gate, there is another lucky white tiger. The zebra-patterned tiger is said to bring good fortuneüêÖIt seems that local university students made it in hopes of the end of the corona virus.

In the treasure hall, there were many small but valuable items such as [Hideyoshi's molar] and [used pillow].

Author: ÊàêÊæ§Â∞èÁôæÂêà
Review: The enshrined deity is Toyotomi Hideyoshi. The gorgeous Karamon gate is one of the three National Treasure Karamon gates of Fushimi Castle. It is a shrine where the chirping of small birds is refreshing.

Author: Honami Shimano
Review:
It is a shrine that enshrines Toyotomi Hideyoshi, and as you can imagine, there are benefits for success and business prosperity.
It was a year-end visit, but there were surprisingly few people, so I was able to look around slowly.
It is considered to be one of the fortune tours, so this time I would like to bring a red stamp.

Author: Craig Cho
Review: I went there because it was said to be a shrine for Toyotomi Hideyoshi, a popular figure in Korean history and also in Japanese history, but there are no people there and it's not as big as I thought. Just a normal gentleman feeling. There is an ear tomb nearby

Author: - S
Review:
Although it is near Kiyomizu-dera Temple and Sanjusangendo Temple, it is sparsely visited and quiet. The gate to the inner shrine is closed, so you can't visit it, but I think it's worth seeing the construction of the gate and stone lanterns.

If you go through the torii gate and turn left, you will find Hokoji Temple. There are the bells of "National Anxiety" and "Reverend and Honorable". Let's take a look at this as well.
